description: From Middle English kene (“bold, brave, sharp”), from Old English cēne (“keen, fierce, bold, brave, warlike, powerful; learned, clever, wise”), from Proto-Germanic *kōniz (“knowledgeable, skilful, experienced, clever, capable”), from Proto-Indo-European *ǵneh₃- (“to know”).

Cognate with Danish køn (“handsome, pretty”), Dutch kien (“smart, wise, able”), koen (“daring, valiant, doughty, courageous”), German kühn (“bold, daring, audacious, hardy, valiant, venturesome”), Icelandic kænn (“wise, crafty, clever, able”), Scots keen (“lively, brisk; avaricious”). Related to Old English cunnan (“to know how to, be able to”). More at cunning, can.

adjectives.description: keen (comparative keener or more keen, superlative keenest or most keen)

entries.meaning: (chiefly Commonwealth) Often with a prepositional phrase, or with to and an infinitive: showing a quick and ardent responsiveness or willingness; eager, enthusiastic, interested.
examples: I’m keen on you. ― I like you.
She’s keen to learn another language.
“Do you want to go on holiday with me?”   “Yes, I’m keen.”
This boy has a keen appetite.

entries.meaning: Having a fine edge or point; sharp.
Acute of mind, having or expressing mental acuteness; penetrating, sharp.
Of cold, wind, etc.: cutting, penetrating, piercing, sharp.
(Britain) Of prices, extremely low as to be competitive.

examples: I just got this peachy keen new dress.

verbs.description: keen (third-person singular simple present keens, present participle keening, simple past and past participle keened)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To make cold, to sharpen.

description: From Irish caoin (“to cry, weep; to keen”).

entries.meaning: A prolonged wail for a deceased person.

verbs.description: keen (third-person singular simple present keens, present participle keening, simple past and past participle keened)

examples: Last night he had put down too much Potheen / (A vulgar blend of Methyl and Benzene) / That, at some Wake, he might the better keen. / (Keen—meaning 'brisk'? Nay, here the Language warps: / 'Tis singing bawdy Ballads to a Corpse.)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To utter with a loud wailing voice or wordless cry.
